Triggering Event: He found her old wedding ring while sorting through his late wife's belongings, the gold band now dull and worn. He held it tightly in his hand, his eyes welling up with unshed tears as he remembered the day they'd exchanged vows. The regret washed over him like a tide, drowning out the quiet hum of his empty house. If only he'd been more present, more appreciative, maybe she wouldn't have left feeling alone even while they were together.
Generated Assessment: He can't help but feel like he's lost his way in life. It's been months since his wife passed away, and yet the pain still feels fresh. Every day is a reminder of what could've been—what might've been if only things had turned out differently. The memory of her standing at the altar, her eyes locked on his, now fills him with regret. What was once a symbol of love has become a bitter reminder of all that went wrong. As he holds the old wedding ring, the weight of what could have been crushes him. He remembers how she'd always dreamed of finding someone who would make her happy, someone who'd stay by her side forever. But now, those dreams seem like nothing more than a cruel joke. Her smile, once full of hope, now lingers in his mind as a bittersweet reminder of everything he failed to give her. Every moment spent apart from her feels like an eternity. His friends try to console him, but their words fall flat against the wall of grief he's built. Even his children don’t understand why he’s so upset. They see only the man they knew before her passing—a kind and gentle soul who loved them dearly. But for him, there’s no comfort in remembering what he used to be; instead, every recollection brings back the anguish of what could never be again. Triggering Event: "While grading papers at his kitchen table, he felt a sudden, unsettling sensation under his fingertips. A dead cockroach, bloated and decaying, adhered to one of the pages. His stomach turned as he hurriedly flicked it off, wiping his hands vigorously on his pants."
Generated Assessment: "Wow, that's so gross. What if I had touched the paper with my bare hand after removing the roach? The thought alone makes me shudder. It’s terrifying to think about how much bacteria and dirt might be there, just waiting to infect me. Or worse, what if I accidentally scratched myself while trying to remove it? That would have meant spreading its disgusting body parts all over my skin—no wonder my palms are still shaking just thinking about it."

Triggering Event: Every Sunday, he'd take his usual route home from the store, past the park where they used to feed the ducks together. Today, a young couple sat on their bench, laughing, his arm around her shoulders. He hesitated, then walked on, but not before seeing her smile, so like hers. His heart ached anew, grief's familiar weight settling heavy in his chest.
Generated Assessment: He stopped at the corner and turned back, watching them for a few moments. Then, he continued walking, but he couldn't shake off the feeling that she might be gone soon. What if this was the last time he saw her? She had been ill, and he couldn't help but think about what would happen after she passed away. Would he still visit the park? Would I find another bench to sit on? What if he never found another duck feeder? If he stopped by the park today, would it be too late? Would he see her again? What if she didn't want him to come back? She had always said she didn't like Sundays, especially near the park. What if she changed her mind now? Shouldn't he just leave her alone? What if she didn't want to talk anymore? What if she wasn't even there when he went to the park? What if someone else had taken her place? What if he visited the park and she wasn't there? What if she had moved on? What if he never saw her again? What if he lost interest in feeding ducks?

Triggering Event: In the quiet of her home office, she hears a soft beep from her outdated alarm system. It's been silent for years, but tonight, it's suddenly active again. She feels her heart pound as she rises from her desk, leaving behind half-finished calculations on climate modeling. The house feels colder than usual as she makes her way to the control panel. Her fingers tremble slightly as she punches in the code, silencing the alarm. But the red light continues to flash ominously, indicating an open door or window somewhere in the house. She's always been safety-conscious, but now, alone at 76, anxiety prickles her skin like static electricity. She knows every creak and groan of this old house, yet tonight it feels unfamiliar, threatening. She reaches for the phone to call her neighbor, her breath misting in the cool air, as she debates whether to check each room herself or wait for backup.
Generated Assessment: She can't help but feel that there must be something wrong with her mind, too. Why else would she have forgotten such a simple thing? The alarm was supposed to go off an hour ago, reminding her of her medication. Instead, she found herself lost in thought, trying to calculate the effects of reduced sunlight on global temperatures. She had meant to take those pills just before bed, but now they sit untouched in the bathroom cabinet. Panic starts to set in, her breathing quickening as she wonders if she'll ever remember what day it is. She checks her calendar, but everything looks normal. Still, she can't shake the feeling that something is terribly wrong. As she searches for the medicine bottle, her eyes land on the stack of bills piled up by the front door. A letter from the bank catches her eye—a reminder about the overdue loan. She hadn't even noticed it was late. How could she forget something so important? She tries to recall when she last paid, but her memory seems foggy. Suddenly, she thinks back to all the times she forgot to pay bills, and how one missed payment led to a credit score hit. Now, she fears another mistake will cause financial disaster. Her gaze falls upon a photo of her grandchildren, smiling and happy. They were visiting last month, playing outside until dusk. Triggering Event: A male doctor, 20, leaves work late to find his parking spot taken by another car, a handwritten note reading "Reserved for Dr. X" fluttering in the windshield wiper.

Triggering Event: A woman in her late sixties, dressed in a lab coat streaked with years of wear, stood alone in the lab as her colleagues filtered out for lunch. She was still hunched over her workbench, meticulously adjusting her microscope's focus, when she heard the laughter. It echoed down the hall from the kitchenette where the others were gathered around the coffee maker. She froze as she recognized her own voice, played back through someone else's phone. "You're just a dinosaur," it said, her words from that morning's meeting now stripped of their context and intent. The laughter swelled, and she felt the humiliation wash over her like a wave, leaving her cheeks flushed and her eyes stinging with unshed tears.
Generated Assessment: I'm so glad I get to be reminded every time I enter this lab that my age makes me irrelevant. This whole thing started innocently enough. I'd been struggling to adjust the microscope settings, but then my colleague told me how he used to handle such issues during his days working at our university. He showed me how to easily switch between different lenses by simply pressing a button on the side. I thought, “How hard can it really be?” After all, we've worked together for 15 years, and I’ve always been able to keep up with him. But today, something about those instructions didn't feel right. Maybe it was the way he looked at me—like I wasn’t even worth considering anymore. Whatever the reason, I decided to take matters into my own hands. I pressed the buttons again and again, trying to force the microscope to cooperate. Each time, it seemed to grow more stubborn, refusing to respond to my attempts. My frustration mounted, and I found myself shouting into the device, demanding it work. When nothing changed, I slammed my fist against the counter, sending dishes clattering everywhere. My colleague rushed in, startled, and saw the mess before turning to face me. His expression turned from concern to disgust as he asked, “Are you okay? You look like you’re having some kind of episode.” I forced a laugh, saying, “Just having a rough day,” hoping he wouldn’t notice how shaken I really was. But he just

Triggering Event: She walks home from the late-night shift alone, the city's quiet hum echoing her loneliness. As she reaches her doorstep, she notices a small, handwritten note tucked into her mailbox: "We miss you." It's not signed, but she knows who it's from - her late husband's neat, looping script haunts her dreams. She crumples the paper, wiping away an unexpected tear with her gloved hand before entering her empty house.
Generated Assessment: Oh my god, I'm so fucking done with this shit. What if she forgets to turn off the stove when she leaves for work tomorrow? What if someone breaks in and burns down the house while she's at the hospital? What if she gets carjacked and they take her to the wrong hospital? What if someone steals all her stuff, leaving her homeless again? What if she misses the funeral? What if she forgets about it entirely? Why can't she just move on already?! Why does everything have to go wrong?! She's still stuck on that stupid letter, what if it's not even real? What if it was just some random stranger's handwriting?! Ugh, this is getting ridiculous. If I don't stop thinking about these scenarios, she'll kill herself, right? What if she doesn't want me around anymore because I'm always so stressed out about her? What if she hates how much I care about her and tries to get rid of me? What if she gets tired of my constant worrying and tells me to fuck off?! This is insane! We're talking about a dead guy here, not some living being who can actually hurt us. He’s gone, she’s fine, let’s stop torturing ourselves over nothing. But noooo, we have to imagine every terrible outcome possible. My brain won’t shut up and let me live my life in peace. Stop it, brain. Just stop. You’re making me lose sleep over nothing.

Triggering Event: She woke up with a start, her heart pounding in her chest like a trapped animal. It was 3:17 AM, the digital clock beside her bed glowing eerily in the dark. She had been dreaming about work again - equations spiraling out of control, data points multiplying like viruses, an impending deadline that loomed larger and more insurmountable with each passing moment. She threw off her blankets, her cold feet hitting the hardwood floor with a thud. In the quiet of her empty house, she could hear the ticking of the clock, each second echoing like a gunshot in her worried mind. She knew sleep was futile now; her worries had taken root and begun to spread like ivy across her thoughts.

Now, whenever we talk about work, I can see the tension in her body, the way she clutches her coffee cup tightly, her eyes darting around the room. Triggering Event: He noticed the same man, middle-aged with a worn jacket, lingering outside his apartment building for three nights straight. Every evening, as he returned from his shift at the restaurant, the man would look up from his newspaper, eyes flicking away too quickly when caught. Tonight, he found a note tucked under his door, typed on an old typewriter: "We need to talk about your wife's accident."
Generated Assessment: I'm shocked that this guy is stalking me. It's probably because I have no idea what happened to him. His wife was killed by a drunk driver. She left him alone after they fought over her addiction. He has been acting strange ever since. He just doesn't seem like someone who lingers around apartments. Maybe it's because he looks like a serial killer. Anyway, I don't want to be involved in this anymore. I'll never know why he's doing this, but I don't care. He needs to leave me alone.

Triggering Event: He found an unopened letter from their daughter, hidden behind the medicine cabinet in his bathroom. It was dated six months ago.

We need to accept that she's really gone and stop trying to hold on to what's already lost. It doesn't matter how long it's been since she passed away. The pain will never go away.
